entries.title: ğŸ“ˆ What is Economics?
entries.description: The study of how societies use limited resources to produce valuable commodities and distribute them among different people.

entries.title: ğŸ“‰ What is Microeconomics?
entries.description: Focuses on individual decision-makers within an economyâ€”like households, workers, and businessesâ€”and how they interact in markets.

entries.title: ğŸ“Š What is Macroeconomics?
entries.description: Looks at the economy as a whole, including topics like inflation, unemployment, and economic growth.

entries.title: ğŸ“˜ What is Supply and Demand?
entries.description: Explains how prices and quantities of goods are determined in a market system based on consumer and producer behavior.

entries.title: ğŸ’¡ What is Opportunity Cost?
entries.description: The value of the next best alternative that is forgone when making a decision.

entries.title: ğŸ”® What is GDP?
entries.description: Gross Domestic Product measures the total value of goods and services produced in a country over a specific period.

entries.title: ğŸ§  What is Inflation?
entries.description: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reducing purchasing power.

entries.title: ğŸ“š What is Unemployment?
entries.description: Occurs when people who are willing and able to work cannot find a job.

entries.title: ğŸ’¸ What is Fiscal Policy?
entries.description: Government policy regarding taxation and spending to influence the economy.

entries.title: ğŸ›ï¸ What is Monetary Policy?
entries.description: Central bank actions, such as changing interest rates, to control the money supply and stabilize the economy.

entries.title: ğŸ’¬ What is Market Failure?
entries.description: When markets fail to allocate resources efficiently on their own, often justifying government intervention.

entries.title: ğŸ” What is Elasticity?
entries.description: Measures how much the quantity demanded or supplied of a good responds to a change in price.

entries.title: ğŸ§¾ What is Comparative Advantage?
entries.description: The ability of an entity to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another.

entries.title: ğŸ’¼ What is the Business Cycle?
entries.description: The periodic growth and decline in economic activity over time, including expansion, peak, recession, and recovery.

entries.title: ğŸŒ What is International Trade?
entries.description: The exchange of goods and services across national borders, and its effects on economies.

entries.title: ğŸ”§ What is Productivity?
entries.description: The amount of output produced per unit of input, often linked to technological progress and efficiency.

entries.title: ğŸ¦ What is a Central Bank?
entries.description: A national institution that manages currency, money supply, and interest rates, such as the Federal Reserve.

entries.title: ğŸŒ Impact of Global Events on Stocks
entries.description:
Global Events can dramatically shift market behavior, driving investor fear or enthusiasm, impacting valuations and capital flows across sectors and geographies.

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
- Stock markets are highly sensitive to external shocks and policy responses.
- Investors who anticipate or hedge against major events often outperform peers.
ğŸŒ Major Event Categories
- Geopolitical risks (war, conflict)
- Natural disasters (earthquakes, floods)
- Global health crises (pandemics)
- Central bank policies
- Political shifts (elections)
ğŸ¯ Use Case
- Investors track news, apply scenario analysis, or use event-driven strategies to mitigate risk or seize short-term alpha opportunities.
tags: impact of global events on stocks

entries.title: ğŸ’£ Geopolitical Tensions
entries.description:
Wars, military escalations, and diplomatic disputes introduce global uncertainty that rattles investor confidence.

ğŸ“‰ Impact
- Defense stocks may rise, while broader markets fall.
- Safe havens like gold or bonds attract inflows.
- Energy prices often spike (e.g., Russia-Ukraine conflict and oil).
ğŸ“° Example
- 2022 Russia-Ukraine war caused volatility in European markets and energy stocks.
ğŸ“ˆ Short-Term Effects
- Risk-off sentiment â†’ shift to safe haven assets (gold, bonds)
- Commodity prices (oil, wheat) spike
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Risk Management
- Diversify geographically
- Increase cash buffer during heightened tensions
ğŸ“˜ Reference
- Council on Foreign Relations â€“ Conflict Tracker

entries.title: ğŸŒ€ Natural Disasters
entries.description:
Earthquakes, floods, and wildfires can disrupt production, logistics, and regional economies.

ğŸŒ€ Economic Effects
- Insurance claims spike, utilities and infrastructure companies often impacted.
- Supply chains may suffer (e.g., Taiwan earthquakes and chip production delays).
ğŸ’¼ Sectors Affected
- Construction, commodities, retail (inventory damage), insurance.
ğŸ§­ Response Strategy
- Consider exposure to reinsurance and construction sectors.
- Evaluate disaster recovery funds or ESG impact themes.
ğŸ“š Case Study
- Japanâ€™s 2011 earthquake led to massive supply chain disruption in auto and electronics sectors.

entries.title: ğŸ¦  Pandemics and Health Crises
entries.description:
COVID-19 and other global pandemics introduce massive disruption across sectors, policy responses, and consumer behavior.

ğŸ’Š Economic Consequences
- GDP drops, unemployment spikes, supply/demand shocks.
- Acceleration of digital economy, remote work, e-commerce.
ğŸ’¼ Affected Sectors
- Healthcare (positive), airlines and hospitality (negative), tech (mixed).
ğŸ§  Investor Response
- Rotate into remote/tech stocks.
- Avoid high-contact businesses.
ğŸ“š Reference
- IMF and OECD pandemic economic impact reports.

entries.title: ğŸ’¼ Corporate Scandals and Governance
entries.description:
Major frauds, accounting irregularities, or executive misconduct can tank stock prices and raise market mistrust.

ğŸ’¥ Effects
- Stock price collapse, lawsuits, delisting risks.
- Industry-wide contagion (e.g., Enron, Wirecard).
ğŸ“ˆ Watch for
- Sudden CFO resignation.
- Short seller reports.
ğŸ§° Investor Tool
- Monitor whistleblower data, Glassdoor reviews, forensic accounting reports.
ğŸ“š Example
- Enron (2001), Luckin Coffee (2020)

entries.title: ğŸ¦ Central Bank Rate Decisions
entries.description:
Decisions on interest rates and monetary policy drive credit conditions, liquidity, and investor sentiment.

ğŸ“Š Market Impact
- Rising rates â†’ pressure on tech and growth stocks.
- Lower rates â†’ boost to housing, banks, equities.
ğŸ“† Events to Track
- FOMC meetings (Fed)
- ECB, BOJ, PBoC announcements
ğŸ’¡ Forward Guidance
- Language used by central banks can signal future policy shifts.
ğŸ“˜ Reference
- Federal Reserve Dot Plot and Summary of Economic Projections.

entries.title: ğŸ—³ï¸ Political Elections
entries.description:
Elections shift policy landscapes. Changes in tax, trade, or regulation can affect entire sectors.

ğŸ—ºï¸ Market Themes
- Defense spending under Republicans?
- Green energy push by Democrats?
ğŸ“ˆ Election Year Volatility
- Markets prefer predictable outcomes.
ğŸ“š Example
- 2020 US election impacted renewable energy, Big Tech regulation expectations.

entries.title: âš–ï¸ Regulatory Changes
entries.description:
New laws or enforcement actions can shift business models or introduce risk.

ğŸ§¾ Examples
- Antitrust investigations in tech (Google, Meta).
- SEC accounting rules (SPACs, crypto).
- EU privacy laws (GDPR).
ğŸ“‰ Market Response
- Sharp re-ratings when regulation surprises investors.
ğŸ“˜ Risk Monitoring
- Watch law proposals, FTC/DOJ investigations.

entries.title: â›½ Energy Crises and Oil Shocks
entries.description:
Supply chain disruptions, war, or policy limits on fossil fuels lead to oil price shocks.

ğŸ’¥ Sector Effects
- Energy stocks rise, airlines fall.
ğŸ“Š Inflationary Pressure
- Oil feeds into food, transport, manufacturing costs.
ğŸ“† Examples
- 1970s OPEC embargo
- 2022 Ukraine war and oil prices
ğŸ›¢ï¸ Hedge Strategy
- Commodities, energy ETFs, options.

entries.title: ğŸ’± Currency Crises
entries.description:
Rapid devaluation or speculative attacks destabilize economies and markets.

ğŸŒ Effects
- Debt defaults, import costs soar, central bank intervention.
ğŸ“‰ Investor Risk
- Emerging markets, currency-exposed corporates.
ğŸ“˜ Example
- Argentina 2018, Turkey 2021
ğŸ§  Monitoring
- FX reserves, bond yields, CDS spreads.

entries.title: ğŸ“° Media and Misinformation
entries.description:
Fake news, viral social posts, or rumors can rapidly shift market sentiment.

ğŸ’¡ Investor Caution
- Distinguish signal from noise.
ğŸ“‰ Example
- False tweet about White House explosion briefly crashed Dow in 2013.
ğŸ” Tools
- Use verified sources, sentiment monitoring tools.

entries.title: ğŸ¤– AI and Automation Shocks
entries.description:
Sudden advances in automation/AI (e.g., ChatGPT) cause sector disruption, investor euphoria or fear.

ğŸ“Š Market Reaction
- Rotation into AI winners (chips, software).
- Layoffs in exposed industries (support, media).
ğŸ§  Monitor
- Corporate AI investments
- Regulatory pushback
ğŸ“š Example
- Microsoft, Nvidia surge on AI narrative.
